abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental assessment develops a
            medical waste management plan for the Multisector HIV/AIDS
            Control Project for Mauritania. The action plan proposes
            improving the institutional and legal framework for medical
            waste management (HCWM); improving HCWM in health care
            facilities; training the hospital staff and the waste
            operators; sensitizing the population to risks associated
            with HCWM; promoting private company participation; and
            supporting the plan's implementation. The plan
            recommends using a modern incinerator for the national
            hospital, using a one-combustion room incinerator (home
            made) at the regional hospitals and health centers; and
            using stabilized side and bottom pits at health posts. The
            incinerator model suggested is compatible with the strategy
            of waste segregation at the source, in order to greatly
            reduce infectious wastes and restrict contamination of other
            non-contagious wastes (papers, plastics, pipes, and
            syringes, etc). All non-contaminated wastes will be treated
            more classically (disinfection, burial, garbage dumps). The
            system allows or the total melting of needles, the most
            feared vectors for accidental transmission of HIV/AIDS.
            Promoting the use of non-chlorinated plastic containers in
            health centers--where the volume of incinerated waste is
            expected to be insignificant--will help reduce pollution.
            Where the use of incinerators is not the preferred option,
            the following alternatives are proposed: chemical
            disinfection, disposal in garbage dumps or burial within the
            hospitals, if the appropriate area is available. The other
            systems (autoclaving, microwaves) are not recommended
            because they are very expensive and require highly qualified
            staff for operation. For liquid wastes, chemical
            disinfection is the most effective one for treating
            infectious wastes. For this reason, it should be given
            priority in the project. The report further recommends using
            a combined system (disinfection and septic tank) for
            regional and rural areas. In the central hospitals, owing to
            the importance of water volume, it is preferable to choose a
            physico-chemical treatment, which includes a disinfecting
            post, although this system would require more study.
